title: Layer of The Battle of Franklin (Nov 30, 1864)
name: Layer of The Battle of Franklin (Nov 30, 1864)

properties.name: 1st Ohio Battery, [James] McNutt Hill
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryAt least two cannon were placed on McNutt Hill, now the O\'More College of Design, directly behind Stiles\' Brigade. The 1st Ohio artillery rained down shot and shell upon the approaching Confederate brigades led by Featherston, Adams and Scott. These guns fired over 1,100 rounds in just four hours.

properties.name: Collins Farm
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryLoring\'s Division (CSA) with the Brigades of Scott, Adams and Featherston crossed over Collins Farm on November 30th to make the assault against Stiles\' Brigade on the far Union Eastern flank. Loring\'s men faced withering shot and shell from the 1st Ohio Artillery in McNutt\'s Hill. Hundreds of Loring\'s men lost their lives and are now buried in McGavock Confederate Cemetery.

properties.name: Harpeth River
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harpeth River snaked around downtown Franklin, providing a natural protection of Federal rear, as well as the Western and Eastern Flanks.

properties.name: McGavock Confederate Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the largest privately owned military and Confederate Cemetery in the United States. 1,481 Confederate soldiers are buried here. http://www.McGavockCemetery.net

properties.name: Nashville-Decatur Railroad
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Nashville-Decatur Railroad runs North-South through Franklin. It runs right up against the Harpeth River (north/south) very close to Leesburg Pike. The combination of the railroad track and the Harpeth River here made the far Union Eastern Flank quite secure. Hood rejected the idea of a flanking attack by Nathan Bedford Forrest because of these natural protections for the Union Army.

properties.name: Position of Casement's Brigade
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryCasement\'s Brigade, Reilley\'s Division, 23rd Corps, was position here the day of the battle; made up of (R/L) the 124th Indiana, the 65th IL and the 65th Indiana, with the 5th TN in the rear.

properties.name: Position of Federal Army, Nov 30, 1864
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Federal Army had arrived in Franklin around 1:00 that morning. Brigadier General Jacob Dolson Cox led the operation and woke up the Carter family, commandeering their home as his headquarters. At that time, the Carter Farm consisted of 288 acres on the south edge of town bordering the Columbia Pike. Their cotton gin was located 100 yards from the house where eventually the main line of Federal breastworks were constructed. The Federal line commander was Cox who supervised his army in a defensive position surrounding the southern edge of town. He used the existing breastworks built in 1863 and constructed others on the west side of Columbia Pike. About 60 feet from the Carter House, near their farm office and smokehouse, were the inner breastworks.

properties.name: Position of Federal Artillery
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe 6th Ohio Artillery was placed just East of the Cotton Gin. The 104th Ohio Infantry to the immediate West, and 1st KY Artillery further to the West against Columbia Pike. The 100th Ohio was several yards direct north of the 1st KY artillery.

properties.name: Position of far Western Union flank
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryPosition of far Western Union flank protected by the 84th Indiana and the 2nd PA Artillery

properties.name: Position of the 120th Indiana
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe 120th Indiana (Stiles\' Brigade) had the far most Eastern Union flank position on the field. To their right was the 63rd Indiana, and further right (south west) was the 128th Indiana. The Confederate Brigades of Featherston, Scott and Adams approached this position from the South.

properties.name: The Harpeth River - Eastern Union Flank
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harpeth River snakes around downtown Franklin. The Harpeth River and the Nashville-Decatur Railroad provided a natural obstacle and protection to the Union far left flank during the Battle of Franklin. When Schofield first arrived with his army on the morning of November 30th, having just marched 12 miles south from Spring Hill, he found the only two bridges crossing the Harpeth at this point burned. His men set to rebuilding the bridges.

properties.name: The Lotz House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Albert Lotz House, built in the late 1850s, sits here. The Lotz family sought protection the night of the battle in the basement of Fountain Branch Carter, just a few yards southwest and on the west side of Columbia Pike.
